subject: RE: [junit] Re: Sample code for using JUnit on SOAP-based service-oriented architecture
msgSnippet: The problem with URL compactors like TinyUrl is that you do not know where the short URL actually brings you to.  If the tiny URL comes from a trusted person,
messageBody:
The problem with URL compactors like TinyUrl is that you do not know
where the short URL actually brings you to. If the tiny URL comes from
a trusted person, it is a perfect tool.



What usually also works is to embed the long URL into brackets "<" and
">".



Andreas





________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
J. B. Rainsberger
Sent: Tuesday, August 22, 2006 11:23 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Sample code for using JUnit on SOAP-based
service-oriented architecture



Mike Foley wrote:

> Trying to re-post the link to the JUnit for SOA sample code
>
<http://http://michael01612.spaces.live.com/blog/cns%212D894EF96C8FC0%21
\
<http://http:/michael01612.spaces.live.com/blog/cns%212D894EF96C8FC0%21>
> 2059.entry
>
<http://http://michael01612.spaces.live.com/blog/cns%212D894EF96C8FC0%21
2059.entry
<http://http:/michael01612.spaces.live.com/blog/cns%212D894EF96C8FC0%212
059.entry> >>
> in a manner where the link isn't broken.

You should try tinyurl.com. They now have a script you can drag to your
browser's bookmark bar, so when you're on a site, you can immediately
translate the URL into something short and postable. I find the tool
very handy.
--
